articles.headline: At Mexican School Hit by Quake, Heartbreak and Dwindling Hope
articles.snippet: At least 30 children died when the earthquake collapsed their school. As the hours passed, rescuers found mostly lifeless bodies, but also some survivors.
articles.abstract: At least 30 children died when the earthquake collapsed their school. As the hours passed, rescuers found mostly lifeless bodies, but also some survivors.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Gustavo López recognized the boy’s clothes first.

articles.headline: Confident Fed Sets Stage for December Rate Increase
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said a trio of punishing hurricanes were unlikely to reduce the pace of economic growth, and it continued to dismantle its stimulus programs.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said a trio of punishing hurricanes were unlikely to reduce the pace of economic growth, and it continued to dismantle its stimulus programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly a decade after the Federal Reserve embarked on an unprecedented effort to shore up the collapsing American economy, the central bank said on Wednesday that it would begin withdrawing some of the trillions of dollars it invested in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis.

articles.headline: Mueller Seeks White House Documents Related to Trump’s Actions as President
articles.snippet: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, is interested in Mr. Trump’s firing of his F.B.I. director and national security adviser and other events.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, is interested in Mr. Trump’s firing of his F.B.I. director and national security adviser and other events.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, has asked the White House for documents about some of President Trump’s most scrutinized actions since taking office, including the firing of his national security adviser and F.B.I. director, according to White House officials.

articles.headline: Facebook, After ‘Fail’ Over Ads Targeting Racists, Makes Changes
articles.snippet: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, promised “more human review and oversight” to make sure offensive terms aren’t used to target ads.
articles.abstract: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, promised “more human review and oversight” to make sure offensive terms aren’t used to target ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: Responding to evidence that its tools had allowed ads to be directed at users who used racist comments or hate speech in their profiles, Facebook said Wednesday that it would change how ads can be targeted.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: A Start-Up Slump Is a Drag on the Economy. Big Business May Be to Blame.
articles.snippet: The formation of new companies has failed to bounce back since the recession, and economists say the trend may be holding back wages and productivity.
articles.abstract: The formation of new companies has failed to bounce back since the recession, and economists say the trend may be holding back wages and productivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unemployment has fallen, and the stock market has soared. So why has the economic expansion since the recession been so tame, with sluggish productivity and, at least until recently, anemic wage growth?

articles.headline: Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington
articles.snippet: Facebook, Google and Amazon are coming under increasing pressure by regulators concerned about their growing power.
articles.abstract: Facebook, Google and Amazon are coming under increasing pressure by regulators concerned about their growing power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last month, Facebook and Google came out forcefully against a bill that would hold companies accountable for hosting sex trafficking on their websites. They said that while they worked hard to combat sex trafficking, changing the law “jeopardizes bedrock principles of a free and open internet” that have been crucial to innovation for decades.

articles.headline: Insurers Come Out Swinging Against New Republican Health Care Bill
articles.snippet: The health insurance industry, which has been cautious about previous bills to repeal the Affordable Care Act, came out sharply against the latest version.
articles.abstract: The health insurance industry, which has been cautious about previous bills to repeal the Affordable Care Act, came out sharply against the latest version.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The health insurance industry, after cautiously watching Republican health care efforts for months, came out forcefully on Wednesday against the Senate’s latest bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act, suggesting that its state-by-state block grants could create health care chaos in the short term and a Balkanized, uncertain insurance market.

articles.headline: Maria Strikes, and Puerto Rico Goes Dark
articles.snippet: Less than two weeks after Hurricane Irma, a new storm made a direct hit on the island, knocking out its power grid.
articles.abstract: Less than two weeks after Hurricane Irma, a new storm made a direct hit on the island, knocking out its power grid.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Read the latest with Thursday’s live updates on Hurricane Maria.
articles.byline: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: Monsanto’s Weed Killer, Dicamba, Divides Farmers
articles.snippet: Twenty-five million acres have been planted with genetically modified seeds to encourage the spraying of the chemical. Farmers worry about damage to crops.
articles.abstract: Twenty-five million acres have been planted with genetically modified seeds to encourage the spraying of the chemical. Farmers worry about damage to crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: Farmers planted a new kind of seed on 25 million acres of soybean and cotton fields this year. Developed by Monsanto, the seeds, genetically modified to be resistant to a weed killer called dicamba, are one of the biggest product releases in the company’s history.

articles.headline: S.&P. Downgrades China’s Debt, Citing a Surge in Lending
articles.snippet: The firm’s move, spurred by a borrowing spree that it said threatens the world’s No. 2 economy, comes just before a sensitive Communist Party meeting.
articles.abstract: The firm’s move, spurred by a borrowing spree that it said threatens the world’s No. 2 economy, comes just before a sensitive Communist Party meeting.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — China and the world received a fresh warning on Thursday that the country’s dramatic debt binge of recent years threatens the stability of one of the global economy’s most important growth engines.
